PRESIDENT'S ADDRESS

Debate on the Address
(First Allotted Day)


    Mrs Lim Hwee Hua (Marine Parade): Mr Speaker, Sir, I beg to move,

    That the following Address in reply to the Speech of the President be agreed to:-

    "We, the Parliament of the Republic of Singapore, express our thanks to the President for the Speech which he delivered on behalf of the Government at the Opening of the First Session of this Parliament.".

    Mr Speaker, Sir, we Singaporeans have, in the short space of the last three to four years, received many wake-up calls in our relatively cosy rooms. In his Address at the Opening of the First Session of this Parliament, the President has elaborated on the challenges confronting Singapore. I would like to relate these challenges to what I see as the three wake-up calls at the individual Singaporean level. I shall begin with the one that is ringing the loudest and most incessantly.

Wake-up Call Number 1

    What we thought were unshakeable areas of competitive advantage that Singapore has are now vulnerable, and this is largely due to a confluence of several factors: firstly, the global slowdown led by the US economy; secondly, challenging regional economic and political conditions; and, thirdly, increasing competition.

Column: 82



    As a regional hub, Singapore will face intensifying risks of losing key parts of the critical mass. I would like now to discuss this against a backdrop of shifts in economic growth concentration and investments.

    Sir, economists are projecting that economic growth in our immediate region of around 3-4% for each of the next two years will be overshadowed by the North Asian region, led by a potential 7-8% growth in the huge China market. If we were to consider this concentration on an even wider perspective and think GNP rather than GDP, then China's reach extends even further. China has taken a strategic decision to invest abroad for a variety of reasons, including plans to secure new supplies of natural resources. According to the Far Eastern Economic Review, Chinese state-owned offshore oil company, CNOOC (China National Off-Shore Oil Corporation), plonked US$585 million for some Indonesian oil and gas assets. In Australia itself, Chinese investment, primarily in iron ore and aluminium businesses, stood at US$1.2 billion at last count.

    Secondly, long-range planes, when available, or huge shipping alliances, may not need to call at Singapore, if there is no business reason to do so. Therefore, an excellent Changi Airport or a successful PSA alone will not get us very far. Likewise, our stronghold on derivatives trading in the region will constantly be challenged unless we give reasons to traders to always use us, and so on.

    I would now like to move on to the twin effects of technology and globalisation on competition itself.

    Sir, globalisation itself is already increasing competition, and technology is accelerating the pace of globalisation. So businesses are now growing slowly, if at all, and only if they adapt. Businesses cannot sit still and let uncomfortable trends destroy them. Not to react would only mean they die out. Businesses really have no choice but to react ruthlessly, and this would come in many forms, eg,

Column: 83

downsizing in response to a dip in demand, very much like what we have seen in the travel business in the aftermath of September 11 (911); secondly, relocating lower-end production out of Singapore; thirdly, bringing in talent from elsewhere to keep the business going; fourthly, merging for critical mass, such as that we have seen in the banks; or fifthly, even getting out of certain businesses altogether.

    Sir, all these factors have an impact at the individual level. Whilst retrenchment at the personal level is painful, it would be better to accept such restructuring as harsh realities than to hope that something can be done by the Government to these seemingly unsympathetic banks or ungrateful large companies. Even if our jobs were intact, we would have to accept that we would probably have to do more, learn new skills and adjust to new working conditions, perhaps all at the same time. For those of us who have been retrenched, new employment would be difficult to come by and would most likely mean taking a lower pay and position.

    Sir, at the individual level, self-esteem will go down and this is where the moral support of the family or the community can be extremely helpful. There are anecdotal signs that more marriages come under stress when one partner, especially the breadwinner, loses his job.

    So what are some of the hopes we can hold on to and those that we should inject a sense of reality? Sir, we can certainly cling onto the assurance that the Government will continue to devote plenty of resources to developing human capital to the whole spectrum of pre-school to tertiary education, for skills upgrading, re-skilling and job-matching whilst ensuring at the same time that we anchor enough economic activity in and from Singapore into the global or regional market. As long as we are proactive and receptive, we will be able to receive help on adapting to changing job and market demands.

    However, Sir, we would also have to manage our wage expectations. For the past decade, our wage growth has

Column: 84

averaged more than 7% in nominal terms and about 5% in real terms. This will no longer be a sure thing, which means that we can no longer use this assumption to make investments or consume the way we could have in the past.

    Going forward, there will also be a change in the employer-employee relationship. We now have less control over our working lives and loyalties to companies will weaken as we realise that companies can no longer be paternalistic and avoid laying off workers.

    Sir, in a nutshell, this wake-up call is all about change, and having to cope with a more rapid pace of change, much of which is uncomfortable. Most of the jobs that are lost are gone forever so we should not hold out for a US-led recovery and for a return of the same old jobs. Instead, we have to continually make ourselves relevant and think in terms of our skills, ie, what we can do and contribute, rather than the jobs we would like.

Wake-up Call Number 2

    We Singaporeans have to work towards preserving our racial and religious harmony, that harmony will not continue as a matter of course, and that external events and stresses can attack our harmony. Until the infamous 911 terrorist attacks in the US, the war in Afghanistan, the fighting in the West Bank and some other events, we did not realise that we need to pay attention to our own racial and religious harmony. Now, Sir, we realise that these external events can surface or resurface old issues stemming from differences.

    The wake-up call can cut both ways. If we allow it, external stresses can undo whatever precious harmony we have built up, or we can become even more conscious of the differences between races and religions and seek to proactively integrate and understand even more.

    Sir, we have come a long way in fostering inter-racial and inter-religious ties. As a small country, we can ill-afford

Column: 85

to let external events and external influences exert pressure on us. In a nutshell, we must jealously guard our racial and religious harmony.

Wake-up Call Number 3

    This wake-up call, which probably takes on a more subtle and dull tone, is that we Singaporeans have to take ownership of our future and strengthen our sense of belonging to the country and to one another.

    Sir, there is a need to bond even closer to increase our survival as a small nation with no natural resources. There is also a need to give the Government full moral authority and support so as to bring about the much-needed wide-ranging and transformational changes.

    The sense of ownership to Singapore and one another is all the more important because of our aging population and the need to help fellow Singaporeans cope with the digital, information and wealth divide.

    Sir, the key really is, how do we react to these three wake-up calls? Do we break out in cold sweat or have we been tossing and turning and dreading the wake-up call, or do we arise and take these changes in our stride?

    If we break out in cold sweat, we should check why we have fears and concerns and how we can address them. If we have just lost a job that we have had for the past 15-20 years, then we can try examining what skills and experience we have accumulated and seek to apply these skills to jobs outside of the natural industry. If we now shudder at how insecure our surroundings have become, no thanks to terrorism, then we should discuss with our friends and community how we can look out for each other.

    However, if we have been tossing and turning, and dreading the calls, then we should no longer wait for the seemingly inevitable events to happen. Instead, we should actively look for alternatives and explore opportunities to learn new skills for other jobs. We should also not allow

Column: 86

isolated incidents of inter-racial discord to fester. We should actively reach out to friends and fellow Singaporeans to gain a better understanding and build common ground.

    Above all, if we have been alerted to these challenges, we can then take all these in our stride - assess what we have to do and how we can respond to yet another set of challenges or changing circumstances.

    Sir, I would like to conclude by observing that we have a lot going for us. We have huge savings as a nation, a sound financial and physical infrastructure, substantial goodwill from the Singapore branding - in terms of integrity, transparency and an excellent workforce - and most importantly, political and economic stability.

    We can therefore embrace the changes to policy and strategies that the Government will have to painstakingly undertake and be receptive to the need for a change, especially at the personal level.

    Sir, I believe that Singaporeans are a pragmatic and sensible lot and the resounding mandate of 75% at the last GE reflects, firstly, a common destiny and appreciation for the need for survival in challenging times and, secondly, the trust the Singaporeans have in the PAP Government to take us through the necessary transformations, and to help us cope with change.

    Question proposed.

    Assoc. Prof. Chin Tet Yung (Sembawang): Mr Speaker, Sir, I rise to speak in support of the Motion of Thanks, moved by Mrs Lim Hwee Hua, to the President for his Address in this House a week ago. Before that, may I offer my congratulations to you and the newly elected Deputy Speakers. I am sure that the high standards of decorum and dignity in Parliamentary debate set by your distinguished predecessor will be continued.

    Sir, observers might have remarked before that proceedings in this House

Column: 87

were conducted in a tame, even somnambulistic manner. There might have been some video evidence of this after we moved into this House, where no corner of this Chamber is left uncovered by a TV camera or from the sharp eyes of the reporters above us. I say this now as a victim of the all-seeing electronic eyes, so that our new colleagues would not, well, be caught napping.

    I am not sure that we will be entirely rid of soporific speeches in this Tenth Parliament, but let us hope that with the measures announced to "liven" up debates in this House, such speeches would be in shorter supply. Lest I be accused of inducing sleep, may I say at once that I believe the measures announced recently would go some way to help foster more lively debates, but the effectiveness of them remains to be seen. How willing will Ministers and others in the Government accept the challenge to re-examine policies and legislation, how often will they accept suggestions to set up Select Committees to examine the language and impact of proposed legislation, how willing are they to engage in debate, and even concede to a winning argument - we will have to wait and see. Indeed, Sir, I think there is one more thing worth emphasising - and that is, there should be a signal from political leaders that our civil servants, the ones dealing with the everyday running of the country, should also listen and may I say, more frequently, listen with their hearts rather than applying policies and rules blindly.

    Sir, if the truth be told, in fact, the man-in-the-street sees the Government in its most elemental form through the actions of civil servants and other public officials he deals with, and not through the comparatively rare occasions when he actually listens to a speech by a Minister or other political leader. If the public were to have confidence in the Government, it would be through how responsive the civil servants or public officials are to their problems, whether it be their summonses for traffic offences, or their utilities bills or their HDB problems or their children's schooling problems. Too often, we have seen replies that are hardly helpful and

Column: 88

the response is very frequently in terms of a negative decision, without any reason being given. The citizen is left in the dark to contemplate his next move, which is to see the MP, who is also in the dark, as he is seldom told more than what is told to the citizen. This gives rise to further appeals and further letters of rejection from officers who follow policies laid down without question. Sometimes, I wonder whether any GLC has a controlling interest in the paper industry.

    Sir, there would be a quantum leap in confidence building if we can have public officials who take the extra step to view such appeals as appeals from an individual rather than from a class. We want civil servants in this new era who do not take comfort in the uniformity of replies. We want public officials who can think. We also want civil servants who can feel - civil servants whose hearts are not left at home when they go to work every day. To borrow a phrase from American Express, never leave home without it.

    Let me illustrate with an example from HDB. (I should state at the outset that I admire HDB's comprehensive replies to residents on every conceivable problem that might arise. I am only using this illustration because many Members must have faced this problem.) I refer to the treatment of cases where the owner in the recession that we are facing now wants to change down from his original choice of flat because he can no longer afford it as he had lost his job and means of support. The stock answer is that if you have not stayed in the flat for five years, you cannot sell, whether you can afford to pay for it or not. If there is a genuine case, if someone has been retrenched and is making a painful decision to change down, why do we prolong his agony? Sir, the way to foster meaningful relationships between Government and people is to allow the official to take the extra step, without adverse consequences to himself or herself, to question policies and to see whether a reasonable solution can be reached, whether an exception to a policy can be justified. Otherwise, we will have a civil service that is recognised as being super efficient, but which remains out of sync with those whom they serve.

Column: 89



    Sir, the President's Address contains much to think about and to debate on. Its key message seems to be that Singapore must "remake" itself to face tougher global competition and global terrorism. Economic restructuring, social cohesion and political renewal - these are the themes that will matter in the remaking of Singapore. Quite frankly, the themes are the same as those in the making of Singapore since independence. What is different is in the ways and means in which we seek to "remake" Singapore.

    I cannot agree more that entrepreneurship and risk-taking must be encouraged, and that our young people must have a more inquiring and adventurous spirit. But I cannot agree, as stated in the President's Address that "developing arts, sports and a stronger civic society" would be part of the process to bring this about, as if developing arts, sports and a stronger civic society is a means to bringing about entreprenuership. I should have thought that developing arts, sports and a stronger civic society are ends in themselves, not as a means to foster entrepreneurship. I am not sure that the founder of Creative Technologies indulgently sees himself as an artist, poet or writer. And the Sound Blaster card, we are sure, does not write music - it merely reproduces it, or more accurately, blasts it out.

    Sir, literature, poetry, arts, music - these are the things that define the culture of a nation, the soul of a nation. They should be encouraged so that Singaporeans can see themselves in prose, in poetry, in art or in music. They add to the uniqueness of being Singaporean. As for sportsmen and women who excel and do Singapore proud in schools, constituency, national or international competitions, they are to be valued for their sporting achievements, and hopefully not for their entrepreneurship potential. Singaporeans draw together to salute such achievers. If anything, they help promote national pride and solidarity.

    We must adopt the development of the arts and sports as primary aims, and not

Column: 90

as secondary aims to promote entrepreneurship. I want to emphasise this in case an argument is made that certain types of art or music have no economic or entrepreneurial value and therefore should not be encouraged or supported. We must avoid this type of thinking. I am sure that some Members will return to this theme in the next few days or in the Budget debates to come.

    Sir, the Address rightly refers to the widening income gap between those who are able and willing to embrace the new technologies and those who are not. We are already in an economic recession - and many Singaporeans have faced the traumatic experience of being out of a job. With a family to feed, and no job on the horizon, it takes a lot out of a person. Many Members of this House would have had to deal with many jobless persons - you can see the despair and the frustration. They have lost their dignity - and they do not want pity. They accept but are not satisfied with an interim grant to them to tide things over. They just want a job. Being jobless affects not just one's income, but one's belief in oneself - and above all, the family's belief in his ability to provide for their basic needs and happiness.

    Sir, I am glad that the Address signals the Government's determination to tackle this problem. Job creation and retraining of our workforce remain top priorities for the new Government. But, one particularly difficult problem which hitherto still remains unresolved is how do we provide for the increasing group of jobless workers who are either unwilling or unable to retrain or find jobs. The problem is particularly acute for those around 50 years old. Who will provide for them? Very often, for those about 50 or so, companies do not want them even after they have been retrained. I believe that this problem needs to be tackled immediately. Do we need regulation or legislation to make it unlawful for employers who refuse to hire on the basis of age, if the applicant otherwise has all the necessary qualifications? I know that we do not want to put too many barriers for employers - but on occasions, some are justified so that we can forestall a serious social problem.

Column: 91



    Sir, as we move from the economic to the political, one of the most positive statements in the Address is the intention of the Government to "widen the out-of-bounds" markers for political engagement and debate, not just in this House, but generally in Singapore. We must once again wait and see how these OB markers will be defined. What is interesting too is how this intention is read by the younger generation. I asked my daughter who recently finished her Junior College studies how she and her friends would view this increase in freedom. Her answer in a way surprised me. She said that some feel (I suppose including herself) that the intention is not quite genuine. Somehow they feel that the Government will still control the exercise of such freedoms and will only pretend to listen. We must take steps to remove such doubts and cynicism among the young people in Singapore - indeed, among all Singaporeans, otherwise the problem will remain unresolved.

    Sir, I believe that care must be taken in this move towards greater opportunity for the people to express themselves. We do not want a situation where the expressions of individual opinions turn into a claim for rights, and where legal action is always contemplated. I know many young people, especially those familiar with the law, look towards well-developed countries such as the US or the UK and bemoan the fact that we do not have an administrative law structure that allows individuals to challenge public servants' decisions on a myriad of matters. But in this, my opinion is that we should be careful about putting such decisions onto the legal plane for it takes away the discretion from the people who can resolve the matters without going through an elaborate legal process. The truth is, so long as we have wise leadership, willing to listen and to take into account individual circumstances in the special case, we should be able to "remake" Singapore, not in anybody else's image, but one that is uniquely our own.

    There must be confidence in all Singaporeans that they will be listened to. But all Singaporeans must also exercise their freedoms reasonably and responsibly. It must not degenerate into a series

Column: 92

of demands based on self-interest. We must have and cultivate a politically sophisticated population - willing to see and understand the wider picture even if it impinges on their own interests. Then, and only then, can the Singapore heart-beat be heard to beat as one.

    Sir, I support the motion of thanks.

    Mr Loh Meng See (Jalan Besar): Mr Speaker, Sir, I rise to support the motion standing in the name of Mrs Lim Hwee Hua.

    The significant events of last year and especially September 11, 2001 showed us that times have changed, and changing ever so dramatically. Globalisation which was just a concept not too long ago has become a reality. Transformations are taking place on the global scale that we need to change our perspective in the way we do business, work and live.

    In globalisation, local happenings are shaped by events occurring many miles away. The terrorist attacks of the World Trade Centre Twin Towers in New York have brought threats to our door-step in Singapore. It is a frightening revelation that even terrorism has taken on a global perspective.

    Globalisation offers us both challenges and opportunities. For a small country with a small domestic market, globalisation provides us with opportunities of larger markets. It also means stiffer competition from more countries competing against us, especially for foreign direct investments.

    We have seen what happened during the 1997 Asian Financial Crisis and the staggering impact on the regional financial markets. Thomas Friedman in his book, The Lexus and the Olive Tree: Understanding Globalisation, used the term "the global herd" to describe the millions of investors world-wide, who can be stampeded into running from an economy by the slightest signal of danger. It is very important that we keep the reputation of our financial institutions

Column: 93

intact and maintaining a system that is open, honest and transparent. When we adopt very high ethical standards in the public, private and people sectors, we will win the trust and confidence of investors in the long run.

    There has been much talk about PSA Corporation's loss of Maersk Sealand to the Port of Tanjung Pelepas in Johor and the competition hotting up between Singapore and Malaysia in port services and the risk of other major shipping lines exiting from Singapore. Malaysia's attempt to compete against Singapore in port services is not new. It was Port Klang, then Pasir Gudang and now Tanjung Pelepas. Malaysia has also developed the Multi-Super Corridor, the Sepang International Airport and Senai International Airport. Singapore cannot prevent external competition whether from Malaysia or elsewhere. The way for Singapore to respond is to do so calmly by examining ourselves, our strengths and weaknesses and take all necessary measures to tackle the competition and come out tops in the long run. I think it is too early and premature to conclude, as some pundits seem to suggest, that PSA Corporation has already failed in its ability to compete. What is needed is for the Government Ministries to take an integrated and multi-disciplinary attitude in providing PSA Corporation with all the assistance it needs to compete.
